pros: None a depressing place. No perks horrible pay.
cons: Too much to list. The executive staff is paid huge amounts of money while the rest of the staff is underpaid and unappreciated. Dozens and Dozens of people have left this year it’s a revolving door.

pros: Great benefits. Great culture. Supportive team.
cons: I do not have any.

pros: I've been with the Foundation for 7 years and during that time I've witnessed the growth of the organization, both in the organization aspect, but also in their dedication to the staff. I have been incredibly blessed with a senior team that puts me, as a person first. Leadership that encourages me to grow, offers opportunity for growth and success, and autonomy. I am not afraid to share how I feel about something or concerns I may have. This is the first company I have felt the CEO and my department leadership advocate for and truly value me. I live with a chronic health condition, as does my child, and my leadership has always been supportive and empathetic towards the doctor visits that may be more frequent than what they are for others. That support and understanding is priceless.
cons: Like any other organization, there are challenges, but I feel like leadership seeks out understanding those challenges. The biggest challenge is one I feel confident in saying, is the nature of non-profit, and that's limited resources. In the past I had felt like growth opportunity was limited as well, but in recent years that's been a huge focus of leadership's, as the understand this is a priority for the staff.

pros: Great work culture. Friendly coworkers. Passionate people.
cons: The company is a non-profit, so salaries are lower than industry average.

review_title: RUN FAR AWAY - FAKE POSITIVE REVIEWS!
pros: It is a paycheck. The only positive thing that can be said about working at the national office.
cons: First, there is a review on here written by someone at the VP level which is clearly written by the person that is the biggest contributor to the toxic work culture at the foundation. It is a FAKE review. There is a team at the national office that have over 114% turnover in 26 months on their team. HR and senior leadership know of the issues that have been officially reported, and nothing is done about it. Ask about the turnover, and don't listen to their excuses as to why (blaming it on other companies being able to pay more etc,). The bottom line is happy people don't quit. Period. Just focus on the numbers. If it is higher than the national average, there is a good reason for that. Numbers don't lie. DO NOT WORK HERE. You will be miserable. It is a horribly toxic work culture. Your health will suffer from the level of stress you will experience. You will be expected to do the work of 3 people because they can't keep staff due to the horrible senior leadership, and then you will be negatively reviewed for not doing more. Forget taking time off because coming back from PTO is so nasty that it's not worth doing. Your voice will not be heard if you try and complain to HR or anyone in the C-Suite. I wish I had listened to the bad reviews on here before accepting a position. Worst decision I've ever made in my professional career. Do yourself a favor and stay on unemployment if necessary - it's a better choice than working here. I realize that's a bold statement, but it's 1000% true.

pros: Great staff and volunteers are very dedicated to mission.
cons: Pay Flexibility Work life balance

pros: The Foundation has a terrific leadership team, driven by mission and focused on the right things. As a nonprofit organization, the focus is on our patients and their needs. Individual voices are heard and appreciated by leadership. Our CEO is an amazing, inspiring leader who cares about the staff and makes decisions based on the things that matter.
cons: As is happening around the country right now, staffing stability is a bit challenging. That said, leadership is working to mitigate the impact on current employees and doing what they can to attract high talent.

pros: Excellent staff culture coupled with passionate, life-long volunteers makes for a wonderful place to serve. The community of patient, caregivers and donors inspires staff to do their best work and we fulfill our mission. The Crohn's & Colitis Foundation is competitive with compensation and benefits and has a robust career-pathing program that allows all employees to advance in their career every 18-24-36 months.
cons: The work in this space is challenging, but rewarding in so many ways.

job_title: Marketing Coordinator in Kansas City, MO
pros: Very pleased with the workload, expectations, and opportunities to grow. Healthy work environment. Co-workers and leadership truly care about the mission, which I see reflected in their work. Impressed by leaders' commitment to the success and well-being of their teams.
cons: Some days get really busy, fortunately folks are willing to be flexible and to lend support. I've never been pressured to over-extend myself to meet a deadline.

review_title: Stay Away, High turn over rate!
job_title: Senior Accountant in New York, NY
pros: The events are nice and you get free food occationally.
cons: Everyone is on edge to getting fired, every week someone is let go. You are disposable. everyone there has been working less than a year. You are expected to donate some of your salary back into the company. They will not train you.

review_title: Personal conversations with head of Human Resources were leaked
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Open door policy to speak to HR which may be leaked however.
cons: Absolutely disgusted upon finding out several currently employees were notified of my personal conversation with head of Human resources. This is absolutely unacceptable, unethical and disrespectful. I am loss al a loss of words but not surprised as this organization is run by some real garbage leaders who is there to just make some money. What kind of leadership is this?

review_title: Toxic Culture, Poor Resources, Great Cause
pros: Passionate volunteers and great cause
cons:
Constant turnover (for good reason), top heavy organization, and little room for growth.
Leadership caters to volunteers at the expense of staff and allows them to treat staff poorly with no consequences. 
Medical benefits are incredibly expensive and subpar compared to other nonprofit organizations.

pros: Connection to mission is strong
cons: Disjointed remote worker policies and communication

pros: From the national office to chapters, the Foundation's staff are an incredible and supportive team! Staff works in a very open, collaborative, transparent and caring environment. New staff on-boarding is very comprehensive and there are ongoing meetings, presentations and communications throughout the year to share mission updates, best practices and Foundation news.
cons: Great place to work, no cons to report!

pros: Flexible schedules, mission oriented co-workers and opportunities to advance.
cons: Department silos, lack of professional development opportunities

pros: Loved the people I worked with
cons: Leadership wasn’t the best and made it hard to complete tasks

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Not being there and moving on.
cons: The most inauthentic management team in creation. Unemployable anywhere else. Employee abuse is rampant. Interest in the "cure" nonexistent. Lots of show, no value.

pros: They care about their employees a lot. Everyone wants you to grow and there are opportunities for advancement. They stress work-life balance and truly mean it. They constantly work to improve how things are done.
cons: Compensation is less than other companies but it’s a nonprofit so that’s to be expected. They make up for it with good benefits and generous PTO.

job_title: Office Administrator in Farmington Hills, MI
pros: Good time off package, flexible
cons: Poor management, poor health insurance, no opportunities for advancement even though they say there are

job_title: Area Manager in Little Rock, AR
pros: Flexible, good pay, medical field , advancment
cons: Poor management, lone wolf, fast

pros:
Good community to work with
Some good coworkers
Lots of departments to explore
cons:
Low pay
Overworked 
Poor management style and it gets worse at the top

review_title: flexibility of leadership with return to office
pros: benefits and paid-time off policy
cons: flexibility of leadership with return to office

pros: What a great place to work.
cons: I would not have any at this time.

pros: Good leadership and mentoring program
cons: None that I can think of

job_title: Event Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good mission, helps patients in communfiy
cons: Unfriendly staff, poor leadership, lack of communication

review_title: Awful Place —Keep the job you have
pros: A few nice people, but not many. Most will throw you under the first bus they see.
cons: Work gets piled on staff until each person has enough work for at least two people. Backstabbing, lying and cutthroat atmosphere. Managers will outright lie about staff to cover themselves. No real direction or management. Managers are not held accountable for their inability to manage or lead. No personal ethics. Truly one of the worst places I have ever worked.

review_title: Decent pay but lots of work
pros: Decent pay outright when you are hired
cons:
Hard to get raise 
Lots of work will get added on as you work there, but your pay won’t be raised

pros: Great Job development and growth opportunities
cons: That majority of the staff is remote

pros: Passionate about finding a cure.
cons: Upper management will not listen to chapter staff about what works in their area. No loyalty to employees who step up when necessary. One or two upper managers control everything. Not sure CEO is always aware of how the field staff are treated.

pros: Amazing and open work culture with commitment to service.
cons: The range of activities is very complex and could be better managed with improved coordination across different parts of the organization.

pros: The only pro about working here is the great mission.
cons: Do not work here. The workplace is extremely unprofessional and there is absolutely no management or direction. People who have worked there a long time can get away with anything with absolutely no repercussions. If you're passionate about the mission, just get involved as a volunteer or donate but don't work here.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Garden City, NY
pros: Working with a community who really needs the foundation's assistance
cons: Hostile Environment at times because higher ups didn't know how to run an office without being condescending

pros: Innovative, Mission-driven, Flexible work, Many remote positions
cons: Lack of upward mobility; The job expectations can be too much for 1 person

pros: Flexible schedule, great coworkers, laid back atmosphere, great volunteers
cons: Micromanagement at the upper levels, low pay & benefits

pros: Collaborative work environment, very mission-driven
cons: Lacked organization at times from upper management

review_title: Great organization with some challenges at the top
pros: Great team with mission focus
cons: Some challenges regarding upper level management at the Chapter level

review_title: Great cause, great volunteers, great field staff, poor management!
pros: The cause is incredibly important and volunteers are passionate! The work is rewarding because of these two factors.
cons:
There is a lot of turnover at CCFA because of poor management. Open positions are often filled by internal staff (sometimes with a promotion and sometimes through a division of work). Promotions happen even if the staff member is not yet qualified for the position. This kind of decision-making perpetuates the cycle of bad management. Once promoted, new management does not receive training, nor do they have resources to turn to when a problem does arise. HR does not seem experienced enough, nor do they have the resources to be fully effective because they have a very small staff and are only located in the HQ office.

People are worked hard, goals are almost always just above what is reasonable, and upper management thinks pushing harder is the way to motivate staff. Upper management is often out-of-state and because they are spread so thin rarely has time to strategize or get to know employees or their territory. Worse than out-of-state upper management is bad management at the chapter level. The review process for managers includes revenue benchmarks, but no standards for staff contentment. I've seen these reviews as an employee and as a manager and am disappointed by their lack of effectiveness. 

I was promoted three times with CCFA, but now I wish I had just left sooner. I've seen two "restructures" in the three years I've been here and each time more funding is cut, resources are stretched tighter, and a lack of communication handed down to staff regarding changes.

review_title: Mission driven, great place to work
pros: Management cares about employees, making an impact on patients, opportunities for career development, collaborative environment, good benefits and competitive salary
cons: Some turnovers, but this is improving

pros: Learned a lot of things and great place to start nonprofit career
cons: I was constantly overwhelmed with the workload

job_title: Executive Director, Non-Profit in New York, NY
pros: Flexible, job coaching, genuine care for mission
cons: Small staff, so lots of work

review_title: Important work done by Foundation and opportunities to learn make for a great career opportunity
pros: CCFA is doing really important and groundbreaking work.  You know that the dollars that you're raising are being spent well and are really making a difference in the life of patients with IBD.  Many staff have a connection to the cause, making the passion for the foundation permeate in your everyday work as well.  There is lots of potential of growth within your program or through other avenues, and management and national staff are always available to give advice and work through a problem, even if you do not directly report to them.  With Michael Osso coming onboard this past summer as CEO I have seen great strides to keep our mission focused on the patients and improve the work environment for employees as well.
cons: As many other non-profits it struggles with turn-over and restructuring often, this is often stressful for all employees involved and the hiring process is very slow.  There is not always consistency in compensation and benefits, so you have to fight for what you're worth.  There are also many lateral positions that each staff works with and you can often get conflicting messages from different departments or managers with different end goals.  More strategizing and avenues for clear communication would be helpful.

pros:
- Staff/Volunteers are great to work with
- Fun, creative, and professional environment
- Great benefits
- Very caring managment/mentoring
cons: Loved working here. Only con is the process for a raise.

review_title: Great pay, but poor management and work/life balance
pros: The organization has great pay rates and benefits. It is also a great experience to work for a national non-profit organization to learn learn key skills that may be useful in your career long term.
cons: Local staff are required to work long hours to meet lofty and often unrealistic fundraising goals that do not necessarily translate into increased client services. In short, the national office provides very little support. In addition, management staff at the New York-based national office have a lack of regard for local staff. Very few senior level staff have experience working in the areas of those they are supervising. Subordinates are often most helpful sharing information from one another, rather than seeking the guidance of their appointed supervisors. The turnover rate was once very high (staff changes every 1 to 2 years), but seems to have slowed down a bit recently. It is so noticeable that key volunteers have asked staff to please remain with the local Chapter so that it can really grow to its full potential.

review_title: Plans for growth are recipe for failure
pros: Some local chapter staff are dedicated and bring much-needed expertise to CCFA.  Many positions allow for a lot of autonomy, so you have the opportunity to try to meet goals in creative ways.  These same positions come with a lot of responsibility, and require you to wear many different hats, so you can gain valuable nonprofit experience.
cons: The plans for growth over the next few years are so unfocused and unrealistic that inefficiencies related to turnover and blown budgets are all but guaranteed.  That will lead to waste of our donors money.  For at least the 2nd year in a row, revenue from walks and endurance teams has failed to meet annual 20% growth.  So we find ourselves yet again crisis mode while the same leadership teams head into a 3rd year of unreasonable budgets.  It's discouraging that lack of competence at the highest levels is never addressed.

review_title: Plenty of Fish in the Sea
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The Work Culture is the only positive part of this organization. Everyone is nice to one another which keeps you going throughout the day.
cons:
-Very low pay in salaries within the organization.  Senior Management however is totally overpaid.  
-They do not value strong intellectual employees and their growth. They let employees sit there for years and years without any new direction.
-The employee turnover is ridiculously high in this organization. Management is to blame. 
-There is no direction or good lead within departments. From my experience, majority of the employees here that I have spoken to in 2018 is unhappy with their job, lack of leadership, work life balance  and/or salary.
-For some reason the organization has an issue with employees taking sick days. Why work in a office that has a problem with employees taking sick day? Just inhuman. Needless to say, this is a non profit that is built for patients with IBD.
-Lots on internal politics within the organization.
-Supervisors/VP's will micromanage you with expectations of you being perfect.

review_title: Can Be A Really Fun & Unique Job
pros: The CEO and upper management in NY are a dream team. The culture and community are lovely, especially in the right chapter. It can be a really fun and unique job if you're connected to the mission, and of course very rewarding. You must be innovative and dedicated to making it work, again this innovation can be exciting and challenging in a fun way.
cons: My direct manager was a very poor leader in terms of guidance on achievement of goals. Direction always came in at the last minute when it was really too late to execute. However, there is a lot of help from co-workers and it seemed expected that this is where one should look for guidance. The issue is everyone is remote and it can be difficult to build the bonds that are necessary for this kind of collaboration. Also, the hours in this particular role/department are a bit all over the place. Your commitment has to come from passion for the mission, there really is no other way to do this job. Compensation leaves something to be desired; but it's a non-profit, that should be expected at some level.

review_title: Stop. Don't Even Apply. Save yourself the trouble.
pros: The actual cause is fantastic. Many people have Crohn's/UC and the money helps fund research for a cure.
cons: Where to begin? First of all, they do not listen to anything that you have to say. They will ask you for "outside of the box" ideas only to dismiss you before you can even finish your idea as "not the way we do it." They ask you to do extra work if you are good and then the extra work becomes more work and then you burn out. They do not pay you anything more for the extra work. They will dangle a carrot for "career progression" in front of you, but there really isn't anywhere for you to go. They recently realigned (yet again) and the people they promoted aren't actual "managers" and they have no managerial training. They do not know how to manage people. They keep changing budgets and goals mid-season so you don't know where you are, but they make it seem like it is your fault for not knowing. Oh and the pay is very, very low.

pros: Very high energy group with passionate dedication to the organization’s mission; provides extensive experience with grassroots marketing; a good fit for people who have a connection to cause.
cons: Very poor decision-making by national staff has lead to low morale.  No proper research seems to be conducted or experts consulted when major reorganizations are undertaken.  A recent move to convert managers to a mobile workforce sounds good in theory, but the CCFA’s plan is to place the burden of infrastructure and technology investment on the employees.  Be prepared to provide your own devices for a job, and pay out of pocket for the ability to work outside of a home office in restaurants and coffee shops.  And this lack of due diligence applies to how national manages the local fundraising groups as well.  Teams and walks are started or goals are set with zero research conducted, yet local managers are still held accountable for national’s poor decisions.  National marketing support is completely nonexistent (or at best incompetent), leaving local managers on their own.  Be prepared to work around the clock and most weekends – the much touted flexibility cannot be achieved.  There really is very little to recommend about working for the CCFA unless someone is driven by the mission.

pros: Working to fulfill the mission and meeting some incredible families along the way. Establishing relationships with constituents and seeing how your day to day work positively impacts their life is the one inspiring thing about working for CCFA.
cons:
-There is little to no support when you start with CCFA. You will go through several routine conference calls to introduce databases, social media policies, mission, etc. However other than this, don't expect training or guidance from your superiors. Sink or swim. 

-Support from national staff and chapter staff is VERY limited. If you join CCFA expect to run a one-man show. This is not an environment that encourages team work or camaraderie. You will be responsible for a yielding a significant amount of revenue for the foundation with little to no support. If you do meet your budget goals, don't expect to be rewarded or even acknowledged for your accomplishment or hard work.

-Investing in current staff (via professional growth opportunities, work-life balance, compensation, etc.) is not a priority. 

-Unfortunately there is an overwhelming sense of frustration among staff at CCFA due to lack of appreciation, resources, & support from national staff. This sentiment can be deflating and quite frankly, a shame. Typically one goes into the non-profit sector to make a positive mark on the world... don't expect to gain this from working for CCFA.

pros: Freedom to run the walk the way you feel it's best,
cons:
Where do I start, I knew from my first day at CCFA that it was going to be a challenge. The computers are extremely slow and everyone has different levels of software (ex. Some computers have Office 2003 and some have 2010). It takes a lot to scare me away from a job but if you see a listing for this job, click the back button quick! If you want to be fired in 3 to 9 months click the apply button.

Local Management is terrible because they smile in your face while stabbing you in the back. Instead of coaching their new employees how to grow, they send emails and cc: all top staff to tell you how unhappy they are. As a new employee, training is more effective than mean emails. 

The training starts off great, the girls are smart, beautiful and young for being at such a high level. That gave me hope for growth. Until you get your goals. The goals are unattainable and they have high goals in areas of town who could never bring the type of money in the time frame they are asking.

I’ve been in non-profit for years and because of this organization I left the industry. 

Don’t waste your time- it’ll just ruin your resume.

review_title: Over Worked and Underpaid. Think twice before taking a job with this company.
pros: Raises money for a great cause. Much needed funds are raised to help lots of people
cons: You will be overworked and underpaid. Plan to work 40+ hours at all time. Management is poor with communication. Comp time is encouraged however once you try and take it , you will only get behind on your work and more pressure will come down on you. There is LITTLE to NO work life balance. This is not a job for a young professional. DO not think it will be an enjoyable position with the amount of workload you are demanded to do. Ask every question possible before considering taking a job here with CCFA. Employee appreciation is little to none. Look at the turnover on the jobs out there. Every day there is a new position open with CCFA, this has to tell you something.

review_title: Going on 6 years with the Foundation!
pros:
It is unfortunate to read some of the negative reviews. Naturally unsatisfied employees are more likely to leave reviews than someone like myself who is currently employed and loves my job. That said, I feel it important to share my positive experience with the Foundation. 

I have been with CCFA for almost 6 years and feel fortunate to work for an organization that has high integrity and is laser focused on their mission. In my time here, I have had 3 advancement opportunities and still feel I have room to grow. 

I love that the organization is nimble and employees from all levels and tenure have a voice and platform to share feedback. 

The organization is constantly evolving and I am excited to be a part of the great work being done internally and externally.
cons: Change is never comfortable - but nothing great is accomplished without change. I applaud the Foundation for not being afraid to adjust course if something is not working. To make those changes across the national organization takes time and collaboration. It can be challenging to navigate around the colleagues who do not like or welcome change.

review_title: Great Organization, Poor Work Life balance
pros: Great ratio of funds raised goes to a great cause and this place brings a large amount of awareness to IBD. Flexible work hours with decent benefits.  Gives a great "feel good" feeling for working here. Exciting & positive outlook ahead for the Foundation as a whole!   CEO is really pushing the Foundation in the right direction.
cons: Work life balance is extremely is tipped and expectations for a single person unrealistic.  Turn over rate is high due to various reasons such as employees being burnt out, lack of growth and/or compensation.   Most common is an employee being burnt out.

review_title: CCFA lacks key competencies in several areas!
pros: Everyday is different.  Honestly, not too many positives to list.
cons: The communication process is terrible!  The 3 National walk staff are negative, unwilling to help, easy to point fingers and very unprofessional.  In senior leadership, there is no one to turn to for support or guidance and if you fail, you take the burden 100%.  The goals increase year over year 10-15% and are unobtainable.  Rather than look at the program or staff leaders, they are quick to fire the key employees on the ground and start over.  There is no positive reinforcement, only negative comments.  Funny enough, if you do well and hit your goals, but the National walk staff "has it out for you," they will figure out a way to get rid of you one way or another.  It feels like it is run by a group of high school girls rather than non-profit professionals.

pros: Volunteers from CCFA are incredibly committed and dedicated.  It's what makes leaving hard.  That and the patients. If you love conference calls, micromanagement and reports this job is just what you have been looking for!
cons: The leadership despite getting a new CEO are still the same snakes in the grass that have been in place since before Michael Osso arrived.  With all the openings they have you can tell even the newest reviews have been written by members of national or those that have been asked to give CCFA a positive rating. If dare speak up or voice any of your concerns you will quickly find yourself on an action plan. You are responsible for all staff turnover in your chapter even if they deserved to be let go.

review_title: Great mission, poor work culture and environment
pros: Great mission, provide a lot of support and education for patients and families.
cons: Not much opportunity to move up.  High turnover. Poor work life balance. Too many mid level managers who do not really support the field. Management is a lot of talk, but doesn't get hands on when it comes to events etc. Management talks down to staff.  Goals are set so high that they are close to impossible to reach. If you fall short of goal in any area you are not eligible for bonus.  Different areas compete for same pool of supporters and often fight over them.  Lot of talk about team work, but team players are not rewarded, it's more of a back stabbing culture. There are some good staff, but they get fed up and leave.  Staff is often overworked and underpaid, compensation at management level is very high compared to hours they put in.

pros: The pros are that there are some people in this organization that work hard and really do care about the mission. However there are some people in the field and at the national headquarters that are horrible.
cons:
- Lack of communication
- HR is a diaster. Everyone person has different rules on how things are managed
- To many managers and to many bosses
- They hire horrible people and people are promoted in the field just because they been with CCFA a long time
- No work life balance
- Money hungry and will fire you on the spot if you don't meet budget
- Working in this "mobile" workforce which is going to be a diaster
- say's there is no money but hire people all over the place, people traveling all over the country- doesn't make sence to me. How about a conference call?

pros: - Volunteers are awesome, I made some great friends and learned some new skills.
cons:
- Extremely Overworked and underpaid.  Many  positions at CCFA can realistically be divided amongst 2-3 people.
- Entry level position, NO room for advancement.
- Some members of the Senior Management team only speak when they need a task completed , otherwise rude.
- Extremely high turnover throughout the company, especially at National.
- Stuffy atmosphere, very cliquish.
- You are constantly REQUIRED  to assist with tasks/projects for other departments.
- You are also expected to be proactive ALL the time and ask for tons of extra work, but expected to get it done within the same 7 hour workday.
-  They preach transperancy and accountability on paper, but it's all lie!
- Some people careers are fast-tracked. 
Good Luck trying to get into that secret society!


If you decide to work at CCFA- be sure to keep your profile active on LinkedIn and only stay for about 2 years. Otherwise, you will be swallowed up by the black hole filled with no hope and you will waste prescious years of your life!

P.S. Be weary of the fluffy, positive reviews on here.

review_title: High Turnover, Lack of Support from Management, Incompetent Staff!!!
pros: Benefits package is reasonable and pay was average.  Will gain experience with the 10 million jobs that you are responsible for while working with organization.  For example, in this particular position you are responsible for special events, fundraising, numerous administrative duties, public relations, development...a lot of hats to wear for one employee.
cons: Extremely high turnovers in this organization, every 6 months there is another manager.  Organization is very money hungry! Fundraising goals are unreasonable.  Amount of responsibilities are unreasonable, especially for the pay. You have absoulutely NO SUPPORT from management. There is no loyalty. Most of the Executive Directors and Regional Managers and Directors are incompetent, have nothing more than a B.S. degree and absolutely no clue on how to run/manage the organizations and the staff. Becaues there great uncles donated big bucks to the organization they all of sudden have a top position in the organization.  If you do accept this position, make sure to have a back up plan.

review_title: CCFA is a great organization to work for!
pros: CCFA is extremely mission-driven and does a great job keeping staff in all positions aware of what the funding priorities are, how to obtain helpful information to pass along to our constituents, and specific examples of where the money we raise goes.  The culture at CCFA has changed over the years and I have seen some great improvements in rewarding employees for their hard work and providing a career path for those who excel in their jobs and are wanting new opportunities.  My colleagues across the country are also a great group of people and fun to work with.
cons: I have found at CCFA if you encounter negative issues or barriers that are preventing you from doing your job, it can usually be worked out pretty quickly if you simply share those issues/barriers with your supervisor and help come up with ideas on how to resolve.

job_title: Human Resources Intern in New York, NY
pros: There was free coffee but besides that, the people that you work with are the best thing about CCFA. It is really great to see everyone working towards the same goal and mission of the organization. It is refreshing to see everyone actually care about their job and what they do for the organization. There was not one unpleasant person I came in contact with while interning with CCFA. Even people who held higher positions are approachable. Overall CCFA is a great organization with great people that is service humanity. I also learned a lot about human resources during my time there. The HR department never made me feel like I was just an intern, I really felt as if I belonged. I could not ask for a better experience.
cons: There are no cons, they are very up front about what they will offer to you.

review_title: Great company with huge opportunity for growth and advancement for top performers
job_title: Executive Director in West Covina, CA
pros:
- Almost every position has front line access to the mission and patients we serve.
- great benefits and comp package
- fantastic research portfolio with scientists working on projects with implications not just for our patients, but all autoimmune diseases.
- senior management is accessible to al levels of employees 
- company invests in high achievers and grants flexibility to move within in directions of  the greatest interest of the employee.
cons: - several layers of middle and vertical management which creates opportunities for growth but can make decisions challenging, but that is being streamlined.

review_title: Fulfilling work that offers great opportunities for hard-working producers
pros: Michael Osso is an incredibly inspirational CEO.  Foundation takes patient-centric approach to all key activities and achieving mission.  Focused on translational research that will make positive impact in patients' lives in the next 5-10 years.  Organization is making tremendous strides toward better therapies and an eventual cure. Excellent opportunities for internal growth.  Very realistic field fundraising goals, with excellent national tools and resources to achieve goals.
cons: Matrix structure can be challenging to work in coordination with colleagues between various revenue streams/campaign.  National and chapter volunteer leadership needs improvement - lack influence and connections to high-impact donors or supporters.

pros: CCFA has one of the best professional culture's I've had the opportunity to work in.  Since arriving here in May of 2015, I've continually been impressed by its focus on building a Class A team and the high value it places on building a great place to work.  It's building a transformational approach to its research program and I'm truly privileged to be here.
cons: Over the last 18+ months the organization has been undergoing a shift in structure and culture.  Change like this can be hard and isn't for everyone.  In spite of the challenges this transition brings, I'm excited about the direction our new CEO and EVP for field is taking CCFA and see great things on the horizon.

review_title: Impossible exceptions and no room for growth
pros: The money that goes to this charity is actually being used for it's mission and it's a great mission.  The money goes to research and supportive services so it's an easy mission to get behind.  Field employees are friendly and work together supportively.
cons: No work life balance.  I was often working 60-80 hour weeks just to keep up with everything. When I tried to get help there was none to be had despite the Foundation continuing to create and hire middle-level managers who are supposed to help the chapters but don't.  The expectations of doing administrative work combine with being out in the community and working with volunteers, board members, planning events, etc are not obtainable.  There literally aren't enough hours in the day to do everything they demand of you.  And if you do get it done and you do it well, don't expect any praise.  The bonus system is a joke and doesn't inspire people to do much more than the bare minimum.  Many employees actually admit to "just doing the bare minimum to get paid while they look for something else".  The HR department and higher management do not take care of issues in a timely manner.  (I experience a pay discrepancy that took 3 years to fix).  There are a lot of promises and the upper and middle management don't care about the chapters, which is sad because may of them used to work in Chapters and seem to have forgotten how hard the work is.  Trying to move up in this organization is also difficult unless you are someone's favorite.  It doesn't matter  how well you do, it's never good enough and there's always some reason not to advance.

review_title: A growing, strategic nonprofit making a difference!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: CCFA is going through a period of very positive and strategic growth.  I am very impressed with the leadership at the C-level within the organization and the commitment to building a positive top-notch culture that attracts and retains talent. There is deep mission commitment among staff, some of whom have a personal connection to this cause.  This is a great community!
cons: There has been a lot of turnover in the past and the organization is still regaining ground from those transitions.  But there is so much positive momentum now to move forward in a new and better way.

review_title: A great mission, a driven staff but limited resources and poor communication..
pros: Great mission and an amazing amount of support and education programming for a small sized foundation. A passionate, driven and hard working staff make-up the great majority of employees.
cons: Constant increase in revenue that makes little sense in relation to past annual performance. Very poor communication by national staff with chapter staff- sometimes its not intentional (likely people are just over worked) but clearly it effects morale and the unity of employees;  and most importantly employees don't have access to important institutional information which effects their ability to best  represent the Foundation within the community.

pros: This position is great if you want to build your skills. It is not an easy job and not one for someone that wants 9-5, M-F. You will learn a lot about everything. There is a little travel (to great places) involved. You will build great relationships with fantastic people. Management is helpful and tries to coach you to succeed. Most people have a real passion for the mission.
cons: Sometimes irregular/long hours. Technology issues. Pressure to meet specific goals.

review_title: Top Heavy Foundation, Who Needs to Listen to The Local Staff More
pros: Flexible work schedule and some really amazing volunteers.
cons:
This company is very top heavy, with a lot of national managers or national staff, who can be very disconnected to what is happening on the ground and being done by the local staff. When you work on the local level, there is not much room for agency in your position, they much rather you follow their lead on what works best for your market, without really listening to your thoughts. 

Many of the national staff or higher ups, come from LLS, so they tend to favor those that come from there, too. And a lot of their ideas for their fundraising programs come from the LLS model, though barely taking into consideration that LLS spends way more $ on marketing/advertising than the Foundation does and has better name recognition. You will here "Well, when I was at LLS....". Can be hard to grow an event without any marketing budget, both on the national level or at the local level. 

Your goals can be given to you about three weeks for before your event (or for some people even after your event), this makes it really hard for them to be achieved or even applicable to your program. And the goals are usually created without much insight for the event/local staff who are actually doing the work. Plus the review of your goals/work ethic is very much subjective. They tell you a 3 is an A (100%) , though the scale is 1-5. It does not make any sense. And there is barely any increase in pay unless you get all 5's. 

There is not much room for growth or advancement within the Foundation.

pros: co-workers, volunteers. and board members who want to make a difference
cons: Where to start…Bosses disguised as leaders, micro management, delegation of responsibilities and blame (but never credit), where only the credit is taken on by management and fingers are pointed for everything else. A sorority of hierarchy where if you're not one of them, you're squeezed out.

review_title: There's a reason for the high turnover.
pros: The pay was generally competitive and there are opportunities to learn many different job skills and functions if you can learn how to multitask
cons: It seems like was bad communication between the national office and local chapters. In addition the senior management don't communicate well or respond to the lower staff. Everyone is overworked and any efforts to help fix morale did nothing to fix the source of the problem.

pros: I have enjoyed the past 3 1/2 years at the foundation. I previously worked in sales and marketing in a deadline oriented job. It was good preparation for the transition to non-profit fundraising. If you are a self starter, goal oriented, and flexible, the CCFA just might be a good fit.
cons: If you are slow to accept change or do not work well in a fast paced environment, this may not be the place for you.

pros:
Depending on which Chapter you work for you have pretty good flexibility.
You really are working for a fiscally responsible foundation, so you can feel good about what you do.
cons:
Volunteers (committee members and board members), no matter how horrible are valued over paid staff. Makes it difficult to do your job well.
Promotions aren't given and there is little room for career growth.

pros: CCFA has a great mission and vision. It's definitely grass-roots based fundraising and marketing, people involved all either have IBD or are supporting someone with it. Most positions are home-office based, so it's a great company for self-starters. You need to be extremely independent and self-motivated in order to be successful.
cons: Some of the pros and cons are one in the same because you need to be a self-starter, independent, and motivated to give 110% to your job completely on your own with little support from other staff and participants.

pros: A great place to work if you are driven and have a vision for what you want to achieve. You will be trained and then given the freedom to do your job the way you want to do it.  The staff is very nice and supportive of each other. Everyone believes in the mission and  is committed to finding cures for these devastating diseases.
cons: Staffing is lean so the work load is demanding, but manageable. Work life balance is encouaged, but  can be hard to maintain sometimes.

job_title: Senior Director in New York, NY
pros:
Flexibility in schedule 
Pay 
Benefits
Technology for staff
Established processes
HR onboarding
Science and Research is well done
cons:
Too much hovering, not enough autonomy given to staff to do their job
High turnover - no one stays for long
Top heavy - lots of VP's and Chiefs who do not do much but talk
Staff morale is low
Volunteers are difficult and entitled and executive staff let them be
Staff are overworked - too much demand and not enough investment

pros: good colleagues, flexible hours and mobile work force
cons:
Fundraising staff is treated like children. Leadership is hyper focused on metrics, forgets that fundraising and non-profit work is "people driven" - its one excel sheet after another which leaves no time for the work that actually pays the bills and funds the research. 

The mobile workforce has it's pros, but also means you're expected to be available 24/7. Many emails from leadership late evenings and weekends demanding information.

review_title: Great people; limited resources + crushing workload
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Kind, passionate and smart coworkers and leadership.  People really care about the constituents and stretch themselves to produce outstanding work with limited resources.
cons: Expectations are high and workload often feels impossible given the staff and resources available. Working nights and weekends (with a non-profit salary) is common across departments from what I've experienced and heard from other team members.

review_title: Chaotic "realignment" leads to misappropriation of donor funds and high turnover
pros:
Cause is a good - patient support.
Volunteers are encouraged to participate on a high level.
Initial compensation package seems appealing.
cons:
Numerous high-level National executives quit or were dismissed during 2010-2011 fiscal year.
Mid-Atlantic Regional Director replaced 3 times in same time span.
Patients/donors told their money is going to "research and education" yet CCFA charges attendees (usually new patients and families) to attend education events that are already funded by donors AND pharmaceutical companies.

pros: Working with volunteers is always a joy.
cons: Culture at Chapter level was appalling. Coming from another non-profit, coworkers would ask me if this was as good as it gets (it's not - this is the worst job I've ever held). Berated for working too little after 60-70 hour weeks. Originally interviewed for an hourly position but was changed to salaried before I started so they could work me to the bone. Zero work/life balance. No appreciation for hard work. Requests for increased responsibility were completely ignored. In short, this is not a company you want to work for.

pros: The Volunteers. That is it.
cons: Where do I even start?!!! It is basically a sorority gone wrong. Really wrong. Worst managment I have ever seen.

review_title: Focusing on the mission can make for a fulfilling experience, but do not expect to be support by management.
pros: The best reasons to work at CCFA are in the relationships you build with patients, volunteers and coworkers. It is very fulfilling to get to know the people that you are directly helping to support.
cons: Management. This is a very short-sighted organization. Rather than investing into employees, scare tactics of hitting goals include termination, often. Management then point fingers to save their own jobs, rather than supporting their staff. It is a revolving door.

job_title: Fundraising Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Very smart and cutting edge senior leadership; dedicated field staff; great mission with impressive medical research program; highly committed volunteers at all levels; good salary and benefits; excellent learning opportunities
cons: Has the usual growing pains for an up-and-coming national non-profit org; needs more field staff in major markets; needs more public awareness of cause; needs a few more administrative assistant staff

pros: Flexible work schedule as long as you get your job done. Mission driven. Great employees and volunteers. Competitive benefits and vacation, sick, and personal days.
cons: As with many non-profits, CCFA requires many hours and employees must be jacks of all trades. As such, there's a decent amount of turnover which creates inconsistency and frustration.

pros: Flexible hours allows more life than work balance
cons: Terrible Management and bad leaders to learn from

job_title: Special Event Management in Houston, TX
pros: I met a few great friends who were volunteers for this organization.
cons: Crappy leadership. Often times non profit organization put people in leadership roles who have no training, very little education, but they may come from families who donate big money so they get the job. My experience with working for CCFA Houston was an unpleasant one, I wouldn't recommend the CCFA Houston chapter to my worse enemy.

pros: Very flexible company if you need to work remote sometimes, great 403B plan, & good amount of vacation days. In my particular position I was also able to learn a lot in a short amount of time.
cons:
-Not a good healthcare plan, very expensive
-High turnover rate due to burnout. A lot is expected from the top down with not enough employees
-Not much room for upward growth

review_title: Hurting the patients that they are supposed to be helping.
job_title: Endurance Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros:
-Flexible schedule: the ability to work from home is very appealing, but what this essentially means is that you work 24/7. Know that you need to be able to regulate yourself and walk away from your laptop for a while each day. But it is great to be able to work from your living room in your yoga pants.

-The volunteers. As a Team Challenge "endurance manager," the volunteers who sign up to raise money are generally wonderful people. These volunteers typically really believe in the organization mission and are really inspirational people. So although CCFA management is terrible, you get to work with nice people (as you convince them to raise thousands of dollars for a charity with terrible organization). 

-Locations. Being able to work with people outdoors and help individuals accomplish a half marathon while raising money was rewarding. Endurance managers are also able to travel to destination races with their teams if they reach the revenue goals.
cons:
-Poor management- on almost every scale. Local offices suffer from petty in-fighting and adolescent political jockeying. National programs discourage individuals from taking initiative and tell employees to not take on extra projects or help out with other program responsibilities. Individuals are hired and/or promoted based more on politics than their abilities to actually contribute to the organization. In my time there, I saw numerous extraordinarily talented and passionate people quit or not be hired based on management's personal preferences and "you scratch my back" practices. It's shameful.

-Secrecy/ No transparency. Discussing salaries is "prohibited" - and with good reason. A quick look at local budgets reveals there are huge discrepancies. Everyone had to sign non-disclosure agreements regarding company information after several employees brought this up locally. No one knows what's going with events/ programs/ revenue goals - management doesn't communicate. 

-Poor technology utilization. The conference calls are a joke: our president can't figure out the mute button and the company is too cheap to invest in group call technology. CCFA spent a ton of money on Salesforce, but it's not being used efficiently. 

-Discouraging environment. Incentives are offered and not awarded. Target goals are constantly changed - so a revenue budget can start at $150,000 annually but be bumped up to $200,000 with a few weeks notice. Upper management will use  ideas without giving credit- so there's no incentive to go above and beyond because your manager will just take credit for your work.

pros: Pay is fairly competitive, not a lot more going for it
cons: Low morale, disconnected leadership team. Often felt like an "Emperor's New Clothes" scenario -- we all had to nod approvingly about a new plan (etc) but couldn't point out the obvious flaws without fear.

pros: Great mission, dedicated volunteers, and most co-workers are great and can be a close knit family.
cons: Placing a greater emphasis on how much money can be raised vs. what benefits our patients. Sad outlook to have in non-profit, and members see right through it. Also work life balance is non-existent; expected to work 50+ hours weekly.... in *slow season*. Give you grief when ask to take benefit time off (vacation, sick, etc). I was literally told to place work before family...

pros: Very supportive managers, and the job gave a real sense of helping those impacted by Crohn's and colitis.  The day to day work was very manageable and there was excellent work/life balance.
cons: Little room for growth. There is no clear career path in certain roles.  Your job can begin to feel stagnant after a while.

pros: Crohn's and Colitis are serious diseases, so CCFA is a great cause
cons: Management is terrible!  The people in management positions have no idea what they are doing. No work life balance. Unattainable goals. Low pay. Regional ED's rarely in office. Promised a large summer bonus for hitting goals and management refuses to discuss that as of October no one has received the bonus that was PROMISED in summer!! They are literally killing their patients that work for them. If you have the disease, run away! Not worth the stress!

pros: It is an excellent non-profit organization.  It's located in New York City and I'm looking for something in the area of where I live now.  They raise money to find a cure for the Crohn's disease and Ulcerative Colitis disease.
cons: My main reason for wanting to leave is because it's too far.  I have to commute over 2 and a half hours back and forth to work.

job_title: Event Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: The funds raised go to a good cause.
cons: Apply if you like to work with multiple managers, numerous complicated internal systems, constant conference calls, cliques, top down management, and unrealistic expectations. All for low pay and little advancement opportunity.

review_title: Started out strong but POOR management decisions turned into a nightmare
pros: Great mission, a few people really care about the disease and patients
cons:
I don't even know where to start. National is more focused on setting unrealistic goals for events than doing the research as to why events aren't doing well, and how to adjust the event.  You can't great a budget by saying increase revenue 14% but keep expenses flat- ACROSS THE BOARD OF THE ENTIRE ORGANIZATION.  Additonally they cut funding for Patient Programs and Education events, which is KEY TO THE MISSION. They work people to the bone, with unrealistic expecations of how many hours one can work in a week including nights and weekends. There is almost never a thank you for recognition for their hard work, and if it does come, it's from co-worker to co-worker, not management.

Executive Director hiring decisions are DISATEROUS!!!!!! I know of MANY MANY chapters who had a great team, great revenue, and great chapter.  Once an ED was promoted, or fired, they rushed to fill the position, didn't take the hints from chapter staff, and kept on poor hires, thus distroying the entire moral of the group, both staff, volunteers, and donors.  Turn over if off the charts and needs to be address. Peoples thoughts, and concerns need to not be ignored.  I know of patients who work at the organization who end up getting sick due to the stress and have to leave CCFA. Now isn't that a little backwards. If a UC patient can't work successfully at CCFA, where can they work?

pros:
State of the art systems 
Large budgeting for event planning and materials
Ability to work from home
cons:
Not consistent in message to employees
Little room to grow an area without some sort of penalty 
Lived in my car for almost 2 years - put 20,000 miles in a year

pros:
- Good Health Benefits
- Handful of folks do care
- Great community
- Nice to make a difference for patients
cons:
- Very poorly run national office. Poor decisions are made for those that run chapter base operations. The computer systems, especially those that run IT, finance are a mess
- No room for employees to stay (ie: Tuition money, advancement) 
- Very very high turn over- people I know have stayed less than a year because they were burnt out
- Have a mobile office now- If you don't like working from home- this job isn't for you. My chapter understood it as way to save money. How about paying the president or people at the national office that are usless a lot less. 
- HR Department needs a major overhaul- just horrible
- Thankless job when the chapter works late nights and even on weekends- my boss or regional staff never thanked me for all my hard work
- Let people go in a flash if they don't meet budget
- If you know someone in this organization or someone you worked with at a previous organization is employed at CCFA - you will get a job...which is sad---- How about giving other people a chance
- Don't like getting yelled at from my manager or regional manger- no professionalism
- No employee moral or feeling like you are part of a team... It is national VS. the chapters all the time
- There is no room for advancement at all- people are brought in from the outside all the time when there are plenty of great talent within the organization

pros: my manager was great. she always held everyone to high standards especially herself. i gained a lot of skills and worked on a variety of projects. i learned a lot about my own strengths/weaknesses and what i was willing to take at a job. many of my co-workers are such great people that i stayed in touch with them even after i left
cons:
most of the reviews are from the chapter POV but as someone who worked at national i can say it was just as bad here. you are run completely ragged that you dread even walking into the building. they hold people to different standards. if you are terrible at your job they don't give you as much work but if you are good at your job then they overload you and never show appreciation. the salary would be ok if you only did the work you were hired to do but you end up doing the jobs of 3 other people who they laid off. 

there is no room for growth. it seems that directors get title changes/promotions every year but if you are the ground level you will not get one even if you have been there for several years and go above and beyond what is expected of you. there are consistently too many people hired for high level positions that create these grand plans but they cut back on staff at the ground level who would need to carry out these ideas. 

in my dept they said they want people to voice their opinions but if you give a response that is even slightly different then what they want to hear you are completely shut down and they hold onto that forever. i learned to just keep my mouth shut at staff meetings no matter how unrealistic i thought they were being.

review_title: Interned at CCFA for 5 months - Great Experience!
job_title: Marketing Intern in New York, NY
pros: Helpful team, friendly, interesting, good work environment. Learned a lot. Was able to put skills I learned in school into practice and because of that learned so much more.
cons: There are no cons that come to mind. I really enjoyed interning there and learned a lot from the marketing team I worked with and the company as a whole.

pros: Fulfilling work, manageable hours, extensive onboarding. You have an opportunity to have a significant impact on a debilitating disease.
cons: Cliquish, topdown leadership. Depending on the office, leadership may be unapproachable. The office is New York-based--which may be a positive or negative to some.  Surprise meetings.

pros: Wonderful mission working towards improving the lives of those who suffer from this disease.  Some wonderful people to work with.
cons: The corporate office in New York drives all numbers and expectations without taking into account the difference in geographic and economic areas.  Many chapters have difficulty meeting their expectations which results in very high turnover.

pros: Great people! The new CEO will hopefully turn things around.
cons: No upward mobility if you are not senior level. Pay raises are hard to come by. Upper management is not concerned with their direct reports' growth. Workload is intense and it is poor pay.

review_title: A passionate CCFA employee who received very little support at the local, regional or national level.
pros: The only national organization for IBD.
cons: CCFA has very little concern for their constituents, offer very little support to their employees, volunteers or donors. Constantly raising goals by 15 - 20% per event with little knowledge of the economical demographics of the chapter.

pros: CCFA is collaborative and collegial.  Communication is open and honest, and the organization is really making a difference in the lives of people impacted by IBD.
cons: It is still relatively small for a national voluntary health organization, but for employees that means actually knowing each other enough for real working relationships.

review_title: take a pass at working here
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: nice coworkers, human resources people are helpful
cons: too many trainings, and conference calls.  They are mostly a waste of time.  Managers are inexperienced with supervising people.

pros: Valuable Mission, true to goals, creative in ways to educate and fund raise. Good, solid staff, wonderful clients.
cons: Had hoped to go fulltime, but budget did not allow it. I would have loved to stay on full time.

pros: sometimes you get to work from home
cons: micromanaged, lack of training and support. You will start and immediately be hit with lofty goals that only a small percent of the country are actually able to reach. There is a lot of busy work that will take up a good chunk of your time forcing you to stretch out your work day on a regular basis.

review_title: I kept thinking it would get better
pros: I was happy to have been given a chance at my role and to learn fundraising. I enjoyed working with patients, my fundraising teams, and some of my colleagues.
cons: There was a lot of turnover. I was being underpaid and micromanaged.

pros: Have been an employee of CCFA for nearly 8 years and have experienced a ever increasing positive culture of professional development, honesty and transparency.
cons: earlier in my career with CCFA, the rate of consistent change was challenging for volunteers and staff.

pros: Great success with research, strong accounting team
cons: Ready-Fire-Aim mentality, poor work-life balance, poor process, Sr Mgmt is not very good,

review_title: Potential to be a better company
pros: Ability to make own work schedule/not typical 9-5 job, great health benefits, continued education provided at no additional cost
cons: Pressure to meet goals, long hours, working on weekends

pros:
Less than a handful of people who are genuine and want you to grow (literally).
Meet all sorts of individuals down from world-renowned doctors to donors with $$$$.
cons: Very high turnover rate so if you plan on being hired, ensure that you have a backup plan!

review_title: Good Mission- Poor Process and People
pros: Good mission with lots of success on the research side
cons: Lack of process and structure, senior management team is disengaged with mission, work-life balance is poor, no professional or personal development training

job_title: National Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Good leadership in my department
Great volunteers to help the cause 
Uses money efficiently toward mission 
Good benefits
cons:
Uses too many systems internally 
Low salaries 
Like many non-profits, too few employees to do the work that needs to be done

job_title: Marketing Intern in Little Rock, AR
pros: All the people you work with will activity try to make you better at your job. Very supportive environment. Wonderful company to work for.
cons: Don't have any Cons about the job. Just know you have to dedicate a lot of time (not a con thought)

pros: Flexible hours and chance to advance.
cons: Under pay employees, unrealistic goals, they ask too much of employees leaving people burnt out, over work employees, and terrible people in elders hip positions. Many cliques and "inner-circles", that you must be a part of in order to move ahead. Little to no support from national staff or on an administrative level. They promote "transparancy", but if you are honest about anything it will be held against you.

review_title: Top heavy organization with significant turnover
pros: Hardworking individuals in the lower levels of the organization, great cause, passionate volunteers.
cons: Upper management is afraid to lose volunteers, even when it costs them staff. Pay increases are negligible. Little opportunity for career growth.

review_title: If I had the ability, I would give no stars.
pros: None.  They say hello to you at the door.
cons: This organization, which I belonged to for more than ten years, gave me the boot because of a reorganization.  They never supported me.

pros: Great culture where everyone works together. Growing tremendously financially and in turn has increased research spending. Very exciting research. Field operations including Chapter and National very strong.
cons: None that I can think of at this time.

pros:
Excellent mission
Supportive middle management
Good relationships between chapters and national
Flexible schedule to make up for nights and weekends
cons:
Lots of travel so a good work-life balance is hard to keep up
Communication is hard because many employees are mobile

review_title: Don't want to share cause I am still working here
job_title: Regional Education and Support Manager in Charlotte, NC
pros: They say they want to improve the quality of life for patients.
cons: They overwork you, provide poor management and their goals and budgets are very unrealistic.

review_title: Great place to start a career
pros: Good pay, lots of opportunities to grow professionally because you will have a lot of freedom to manage events so long as you are hitting fundraising goals
cons: Lots of turnover. Not enough support from leadership.

job_title: Fundraising Services Manager, IT Department in New York, NY
pros: The cause and the people I worked with were great. Learned a lot of great technical skills.
cons: There was a high turnover rate so it was frustrating to always train new people.

pros: Good pay and benefits.  Work from home.
cons: Awful management.  No one talks to each other.  Lines of communication are unclear.  And the HQ staff is condescending.

pros: Good coworkers, important cause which helps motivate you through the high work load.
cons: Way more than  9-5, many nights to work to engage with volunteers

pros: Great people, very relaxing working environment, learn alot of sutff.
cons: The pay is not necessarily the best, but it is still a great learning experience

pros: Wonderful grateful patients, excellent fundraising opportunities and great leaders.
cons: Salaries could be higher and more positions needs to be created for elevation of great employees.

pros: Great people & benefits.  Positive work environment.
cons: Some logistical issues at time being coast to coast

review_title: Good work/life balance but lots of pressure to meet revenue goals.
pros: Good work/life balance. Great health benefits.
cons: Lots of pressure to meet revenue goals.

pros: Flexible schedule,  good colleagues,  local
cons: Far too much repetitive reporting, micro management,  ineffective Senior staff

pros: Good people, a ton of HR resources and flexible work schedule
cons: It is a great place to work! No cons.

pros: Flexible schedule and great mission
cons: Little direction, the expectation to work all the time

pros: Friendly environment, opportunity for advancement.
cons: better options for health care would be nice.

pros: Great coworkers, supportive staff, decent salary for non-profit
cons: Lots of evening and weekend hours

pros: Some flexibility, amazing cause, wonderful volunteers
cons: There was a lot of turnover of staff

pros: Great people who really believe in the mission
cons: Micro-managers to the extreme. Unrealistic expectations

pros: Mission, people and impact of work
cons: Long hours and at times unfocused

job_title: Take Steps Walk Manager in New York, NY
pros: They have a good benefits package
cons: not great work life balance

pros: family oriented, flexible foundation to work for
cons: onboarding process is less than desirable

pros: Good community of volunteers and donors.
cons: Bad management. Low pay.
